The catalytic pyrolysis and co-pyrolysis of PP and PET with HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst was conducted for various catalyst to feedstock (CF) ratios, PP to PET ratios, and heating rates using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA). The Flynn-Wall-Ozawa (FWO) isoconversional approach was used to determine apparent activation energies for the non-catalytic and catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET. An nth-order reaction scheme was used to model the pyrolysis at various operating conditions through the optimization of the associated kinetic parameters. Additional TGA experiments were conducted with used catalysts to gain insight into catalyst deactivation, and it was found that the inclusion of PET led to more severe deactivation. Collidine temperature programmed desorption (TPD) indicated the loss of external acid sites for catalysts coked by PET pyrolysis, explaining the severe deactivation. Catalyst deactivation was incorporated into the kinetic modelling approach, so that degradation profiles could be predicted for experiments with the used catalysts. Graphical Abstract Keywords Catalytic pyrolysis Kinetic modelling Deactivation Polypropylene PET Data availability The authors do not have permission to share data. 1 Introduction The treatment and disposal of plastic waste is one of the largest environmental issues facing the world today. In 2015 it was estimated that 302 million metric tons (Mt) of plastic waste was generated globally, and only 9 % of this waste was recycled [1]. Polypropylene (PP) had the 2nd highest amount of waste generated (55 Mt), and polyethylene terephthalate (PET) had the 5th highest amount of waste generated (32 Mt) of the various polymer types [1]. Pyrolysis is a promising method for the treatment of plastic waste, as it can convert waste into valuable chemicals and fuel through heating in an inert environment. One advantage of pyrolysis is that it can treat mixed plastics with various polymer types, which is a major shortcoming of mechanical recycling [2]. While the ability of processing mixed plastic waste can help with sorting procedures, it also allows for the processing of inherently mixed plastic wastes, such as multilayer packaging. Multilayer packaging is known to have high percentages of polyolefins, such as PP, which act as a moisture barrier and provide mechanical stability, as well as high percentages of PET which acts as an oxygen barrier [3]. Polyolefins are ideal pyrolysis feedstocks, as their high H:C ratio and absence of heteroatoms can lead to high yields of hydrocarbon rich pyrolysis oil, which can be treated in refineries alongside crude oil [4,5]. The pyrolysis of PET is however not as ideal, as its high oxygen content and low H:C ratio can lead to the formation of waxy oxygenated compounds such as benzoic acid which can clog reactor lines, and reduce the quality of pyrolysis oil [6]. The pyrolysis of PET can become more favorable when a zeolite catalyst is included in the process, as the catalyst aids in deoxygenation reactions which decrease the yield of benzoic acid, and increase the yield of benzene [7,8]. Zeolite catalysts can also aid in the pyrolysis of polyolefins by cracking down larger hydrocarbons into valuable chemicals such as ethylene and propylene [9]. It has been shown that utilizing modified HZSM-5 catalysts for the catalytic pyrolysis of polyolefins led to a reduced energy demand and carbon footprint for the production of high value chemicals in comparison with non-catalytic pyrolysis combined with subsequent steam reforming [10]. For both polymers, zeolites can help to decrease the temperature needed for the degradation of plastic waste, thus reducing the energy requirement for the process [11,12]. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) can be used to determine the weight loss profile of polymers during the pyrolysis process as a function of temperature and time. TGA experiments can demonstrate the extent to which a zeolite catalyst can decrease the temperature needed for polymer decomposition. Through running TGA experiments at various heating rates one can apply isoconversional methods to obtain an apparent activation energy for the process [13,14]. Through use of the Kissinger isoconversional method, it was shown that the addition of various zeolites at a 7:1 catalyst:feedstock (CF) ratio were able to decrease the apparent activation energy for PP pyrolysis from 114 kJ/mol to 51–98 kJ/mol [15]. The apparent activation energy for catalytic pyrolysis determined via isoconversional approach is known to be dependent on the CF ratio which is used [16,17]. Certain kinetic modelling approaches have been created for catalytic pyrolysis which allows for one set of kinetic parameters to model the degradation of plastic waste independent of the CF ratio or heating rate which is used [18,19]. This modelling approach was used in our previous work for the pyrolysis and co-pyrolysis of LDPE and PET with HZSM-5, H-Beta, and HY zeolite catalysts [12]. While the model was able to predict the degradation behavior based on which LDPE:PET ratio was used, only one CF ratio (1:1) and one heating rate (10 °C min−1) were used for the modelling. In this work it is our aim to test the catalyst which resulted in the lowest solid residual from our previous study (HZSM-5) for the pyrolysis of PP and PET at various CF ratios, heating rates, and PP:PET ratios, so that a robust set of kinetic parameters can be obtained to model the catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET for various operating conditions. During the catalytic pyrolysis of plastic waste, a high percentage of coke can form on the catalyst, especially for PET. The formation of coke can hinder active sites as well as block zeolite pores, leading to an overall decrease in catalyst activity, i.e. catalyst deactivation [20]. For the continuous pyrolysis of polyolefins with zeolite catalysts, it has been shown that as the catalyst becomes deactivated by coking, the yield of target products such as C2-C4 olefins begin to decrease [21]. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption has shown that coked catalysts from polyolefin pyrolysis have a decreased acidity [22]. Catalyst deactivation for polyolefin pyrolysis has been studied with TGA by running subsequent experiments over the same catalyst, and observing the shift in degradation profiles which occur for the used catalysts [23,24]. While catalyst deactivation phenomenon has been studied in a variety of ways for polyolefin pyrolysis, to the author’s knowledge no studies have been conducted investigating the impact of PET on catalyst deactivation. Thus, in this study pyrolysis experiments were conducted with the used catalysts coked by both PP and PET for insight on how coke from the two polymers affected the deactivation. It has previously been shown that catalyst deactivation can be predicted via kinetic modelling for polyolefins [25]. In this study this deactivation modelling was expanded upon, to predict deactivation which can occur from the inclusion of PET. In addition, the adsorption and subsequent temperature programmed desorption of pyridine and collidine were conducted for the fresh and used catalysts, in order to determine the effect of coking on the zeolite acidity. Nitrogen physisorption was used as an additional technique to characterize the fresh and used catalysts, to gain insight on how coke from the two polymers affect the surface properties of the catalyst. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Isotactic polypropylene pellets were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich which had a reported Mw of ∼250,000 mol−1 and a melt flow rate of 0.9 ml−1 at 25 °C. The pellets were milled using a SPEX SamplePrep Freezer/Mill. The resulting polymer powder was then sieved in a sieve shaker and a particle size less than 125 µm and greater than 53 µm was obtained to be used for the experiments. Polyethylene terephthalate powder was obtained from Goodfellow. The powder was specified to be semi crystalline copolymer with > 40 % crystallinity, an inherent viscosity of 0.80 dl g−1, and 1 ppm of acetaldehyde as an additive. The PET powder was also sieved to a particle size of less than 125 µm and greater than 53 µm prior to experimental use. HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst with an SiO2/Al2O3 ratio of 23 (CBV2314) was purchased from Zeolyst International. For calcination, 0.5 mg of the catalyst was loaded into an alumina crucible. The crucible was placed in a quartz tube furnace, with 100 mL min−1 of air flow. The tube furnace was heated at 3 °C min−1 to 550 °C, and held at 550 °C for 5 h, before returning to room temperature. After cooling, the calcined HZSM-5 was transferred to a glovebox to be stored before experimental use. 2.2 Catalytic pyrolysis experiments via thermogravimetric analysis A TA instruments SDT Q600 DSC-TGA thermal analyzer was used to determine the degradation profiles of PP, PET, and their mixtures for various CF ratios. Nitrogen (Linde, 99.999 %) was used as the carrier gas, with a flow rate of 100 mL min−1. Heating rates were varied from 5 to 20 °C min−1. Mixtures of the two polymers and HZSM-5 were made in glass vials prior to catalytic pyrolysis experiments. The weight ratio of the polymers and catalysts added to the vial depended on the CF ratio and PP:PET ratio set for the given experiment. Once added to the vial, the polymer and catalyst were physically mixed with a spatula for a period of 5 min to obtain a homogenous mixture. A given weight of the mixture was added to the TGA crucible, so that 4 mg of polymer would be pyrolyzed. For example, for an experiment with a CF ratio of 2, 12 mg of the polymer-catalyst mixture was added to the TGA crucible. The polymer weight percent and the derivative polymer weight percent were calculated by subtracting a catalyst blank experiment from the pyrolysis experiment using Eqn. S1 – S3, as is explained in the supporting information. All catalytic pyrolysis experiments were repeated at least twice to ensure adequate repeatability. The standard deviation in the solid residual remaining for a given experimental condition varied between 0.2 % and 4.8 %, and on average was 1.2 %. Repeated runs for a given experimental condition are plotted in Fig. S4. After certain pyrolysis experiments, the used catalyst was collected so that it could be used in a subsequent run to gain insight on catalyst deactivation. A larger CF ratio of 2 was used for these experiments, in order to aid in the collection of used catalyst. A minimum of three experiments were conducted for collection of the used catalyst. One portion of the used catalyst was used to produce a new mixture with the polymers to be used for a subsequent pyrolysis experiment, while the other portion was saved for the blank catalyst experiment. In addition to being used for subsequent pyrolysis experiments, used catalysts were also collected for acidity determination as outlined in Section 2.3. 2.3 Pyridine and collidine temperature programmed desorption for determination of catalyst acidity Pyridine (99.8 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and 2,4,6-Trimethylpyridine (99 %, Sigma-Aldrich), also referred to as collidine, were used as probe molecules for insight on the acidity of the fresh and used HZSM-5 catalyst. For adsorption of the probe molecules a saturator was used in combination with a tube furnace. A diagram of the adsorption furnace can be seen in Fig. S1. For the adsorption process 20–30 mg of catalyst was placed in an alumina crucible which was then placed in a quartz tube furnace. 200 mL min−1 of nitrogen (99.999 %, Linde) flowed through the furnace as the temperature was heated to 207 °C and held for 30 min in order to remove any moisture from the catalyst. Then the nitrogen flow was re-directed to flow through a glass saturator filled with the probe molecule of choice before flowing through the tube furnace. The saturator was held in an ice water thermos. Flow was directed through the saturator for a period of 2 h, while the tube furnace was kept at 207 °C, before the flow was redirected to give pure nitrogen flow through the furnace. A temperature of 207 °C was chosen as it is a proven temperature which can be used for the adsorption of pyridine to acid sites in HZSM-5 [26]. The furnace was kept at 207 °C under pure nitrogen flow for 30 min in order to remove any physisorbed probe molecules. The furnace was then cooled to room temperature. Once the furnace was cooled, the pyridine or collidine adsorbed catalyst was collected and then subjected to a temperature programmed desorption (TPD) method in the TGA. For the TPD experiment, ∼10 mg of catalyst with adsorbed probe molecule was added to the TGA crucible. 100 mL min−1 of nitrogen flow was used. The furnace was heated to 200 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 and held for 30 min in order to remove moisture and any remaining physisorbed probe molecules. It is known that physisorbed collidine is removed from zeolite catalysts below 200 °C [27]. After the hold at 200 °C, the temperature was ramped to 1000 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1 and held for 15 min. The loss of weight during the temperature ramp to 1000 °C and its subsequent hold was used to determine the number of adsorbed molecules, and thus the catalyst acidity. An experiment subjecting either a fresh or used HZSM-5 catalyst without any adsorbed probe molecule, to the same TPD method was needed in order to subtract out weight change which was observed during the TPD run which was not due to probe molecule desorption. Equations for the probe molecule TPD (Eqn. S4-S8), as well as associated figures (Fig. S2 – S3) can be found in the supporting information. Pyridine and collidine TPD experiments were conducted at least twice to ensure experimental repeatability. 2.4 Nitrogen physisorption for surface analysis of fresh and used catalysts To conduct nitrogen physisorption experiments of the fresh and used catalysts, a 3Flex surface analysis instrument (Micromeritics) was used. 25 mg of catalyst was added to an analysis tube, and then subjected to a degas procedure. The fresh catalyst was degassed at 300°C under vacuum for 10 h, where the used catalysts were degassed at 200 °C for 5 h to limit the extent of coke removal from the catalyst. After the degas procedure, the catalysts were reweighed, and this weight was used to calculate the various surface properties. Analysis was conducted at 77 K and partial pressure values from 1E-5–0.99 were recorded. Nine partial pressure values in the range of 0.001–0.01 were used to compute the BET surface area, and 8 partial pressure values in the range of 0.08–0.3, resulting in a thickness range of 0.35–0.5 nm, were used with the Harkins-Jura equation for t-plot analysis to calculate the micropore volume, micropore area, and external surface area. The mesopore volume was calculated by summing the total volume of pores with pore widths between 2 and 50 nm determined by the BJH pore distribution from the adsorption isotherm. 2.5 Flynn-Wall-Ozawa method for isoconversional activation energy determination The Flynn-Wall-Ozawa (FWO) method was used to determine activation energy values for the individual pyrolysis of PP and PET both without catalyst, and with catalyst at a CF ratio of 1. Pyrolysis experiments were run at three different heating rates of 5 °C min−1, 10 °C min−1, and 20 °C min−1. The extent of conversion could be calculated for the experiments by referencing the obtained polymer weight% curves: (1) α i = 100 % − Polymer Weight % i 100 % − Polymer Weight % T = 800 ° C where α i is the conversion at some time = i, and Polymer Weight % T = 800 ° C is the polymer weight percent left at the end of the pyrolysis process. In the isoconversional approach, the reaction rate can be expressed as: (2) d α dT = A β exp − E RT f ( α ) where A is the pre-exponential factor [min−1], β is the heating rate [K min−1], E is the activation energy [kJ mol−1], R is the universal gas constant, and f ( α ) is the reaction model. For this work, a 1st order reaction model was assumed, which gives f α = 1 − α and a corresponding integral of g α = − ln ( 1 − α ) . The FWO method uses Doyle’s approximation to integrate the reaction rate equation, simplifying it to be: (3) ln β = ln AE Rg ( α ) − 5.331 − 1.052 E RT Plotting ln β as a function of 1 T for the various heating rates at constant conversion values gives a straight line whose slope and intercept can be used to calculate the activation energy and pre-exponential factor for the given conversion value. The average activation energy and pre-exponential factors obtained from the FWO method for the non-catalytic and catalytic pyrolysis were then used as initial guesses for the nth-order modelling approach. 2.6 Least-squares nth-order lumped kinetic modelling Lumped model fitting approach is a technique which can be used to model the catalytic degradation of plastic waste at various CF ratios and heating rates [18,19]. In our previous work, the lumped model fitting approach was modified to allow for the catalytic co-pyrolysis of LDPE and PET, providing individual reaction schemes for both of the polymers [12]. The same scheme can be used for this work, substituting PP in for LDPE: (R1) PP G 1 → k NC , P (R2) PP + aC 1 + a → k C , P 1 PPC γ G 2 → k C , P 2 + 1 − γ Coke P + a C coked + γ aC (R3) PET δ G 3 → k NC , P + 1 − δ Char (R4) PET + bC 1 + b → k C , T 1 PETC ε G 4 → k C , T 2 + 1 − ε Coke T + b C coked + b ε C The stoichiometric coefficients of a and b represent the grams of catalyst per gram of PP and PET necessary to obtain the complexes of PPC and PETC respectively, where PPC represents PP bound to catalyst sites, and PETC represents PET bound to catalyst sites. γ and ε represent the fraction of catalyst bound polymer which is converted to gaseous species G2 and G4 respectively. The other fractions, 1 − γ and 1 − ε represent the fraction of bound polymer which is converted to coke. γ and ε are a function of how much coke is present on the catalyst being used, and is explained further in Eqs. (9) and (10). δ is the fraction of PET which is converted to gaseous species G3 during the non-catalytic pyrolysis of PET. The rate constant k used for each step in the proposed scheme is expressed by the Arrhenius law: (4) k cat , pol , # = A cat , pol , # × exp ( − E cat , pol , # RT ) where “cat” is labeled as NC for the non-catalytic reaction, and is labeled as C for the catalytic reactions, pol is labeled as P for the PP reaction pathways, and as T for the PET pathways, and # is labeled as 1 for the first step in the catalytic pathway, labeled as 2 for the second step, and is not needed for the non-catalytic pathway. A is the pre-exponential factor [ s − 1 ] , E is the apparent activation energy [ kJ mol − 1 ] , R is the universal gas constant [ 8.314 × 10 − 3 kJ mol − 1 K − 1 ] , and T is the absolute temperature [ K ] . The lumped model fitting approach has also been shown to model how using HZSM-5 for subsequent runs results in catalyst deactivation, leading to polymer degradation at higher temperatures [25]. In order to capture catalyst deactivation phenomena in the modelling process, a new term for catalyst activity, denoted as ϕ, is introduced in which: (5) ϕ pol # = exp [ − d pol # , P × % Coke P + d pol # , T × % Coke T ] where “pol” denotes the polymer in which the deactivation term is being applied to, # denotes the step in the catalytic pathway (either 1 or 2), d pol# , P is a constant which determines the magnitude of deactivation which occurs from coke formed from PP, and d pol# , T is a constant which determines the magnitude of deactivation which occurs from coke formed from PET. %CokeP is the mass percentage of coke from PP on the used catalyst and %CokeT is the mass percentage of coke from PET on the used catalyst. The %Coke terms are defined as follows: (6) % Coke P = 100 [ Coke P ] [ C ] t = 0 + Coke P + [ Coke T ] (7) % Coke T = 100 [ Coke T ] [ C ] t = 0 + Coke P + [ Coke T ] where [ Coke P ] represents the mass fraction of coke formed from PP, [ Coke T ] represents the mass fraction of coke formed from PET, and [ C ] t = 0 represents the mass fraction of catalyst which was used for the initial pyrolysis experiment. A detailed description of the mass balances used to calculate [ Coke P ] , [ Coke T ] , and [ C ] t = 0 can be found in the supporting information. It has been previously determined that the coke yield for catalytic pyrolysis experiments decreases with increasing levels of coke on the catalyst [25]. Thus, the stoichiometric coefficients of γ and ε should be dependent on the percentage of coke which is on the catalyst at the beginning of a given experiment, where the total coke percentage, % Coke total , is defined as: (8) % Coke total = % Coke P + % Coke T The dependence of the stoichiometric coefficients on the total coke percentage is defined to be as follows: (9) γ % Coke total = 1 − C f , γ C f , γ + f γ × ( % Coke total / 100 ) n γ (10) ε % Coke total = 1 − C f , ε C f , ε + f ε × ( % Coke total / 100 ) n ε where C f , f , and n are constants, similar to those used by previous works utilizing kinetic modelling to predict catalyst deactivation phenomenon for the catalytic pyrolysis of polyolefins [25]. A list of differential equations (Eqn. S9 – S21) as well as other relevant equations (Eqn. S22 – S30) which are used to model the polymer degradation can be found in the supporting information. The differential equations were solved for using Euler’s method in Microsoft Excel. The Fit% for the polymer weight% curves and for the derivative polymer weight% (DTG) curves were calculated in the temperature range of 150–600 °C using equations S31 – S38. The sum of the Fit%wt% and Fit%DTG for all modelled experiments were used as the objective function (Eqn. S39). The solver tool in Excel found model variables to optimize the fit for 28 different experimental conditions by maximizing the objective function. A list of the experiments included in the model optimization can be found in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of operating conditions on catalytic pyrolysis The catalytic pyrolysis of PP was conducted at various CF ratios. The resulting polymer weight percent and derivative weight percent curves can be seen in Fig. 1. For non-catalytic pyrolysis the maximum degradation temperature (Tmax) is seen to be 461 °C. The addition of catalyst at a CF ratio of 0.5 drastically decreases Tmax to 351 °C. Increasing the CF ratio to 1 and 2 further decreased Tmax to 296 °C and 280 °C respectively. The smaller shift in Tmax between CF ratios of 1 and 2 indicates a saturation behavior, in which adding more catalyst does not further decrease the degradation temperature. Similar saturation behaviors have been observed for the catalytic pyrolysis of polyolefins at various CF ratios [18,28]. While increasing the CF ratio has the benefit of lower degradation temperatures, it also leads to a higher yield of solid residual left in the TGA crucible, which can be interpreted as catalytic coke. A zoomed in portion of the polymer weight percent curve is shown in Fig. 1 to demonstrate this difference. Higher CF ratios used for the catalytic pyrolysis of polyolefins are known to increase the extent of secondary reactions, where light olefins react to form aromatic hydrocarbons, which can serve as coke precursors [9], thus explaining the trend which is seen. The resulting TGA curves for the pyrolysis of PET at various CF ratios can be seen in Fig. 2. Dissimilar to PP, the addition of catalyst does little to decrease the degradation temperature for PET. The Tmax for PET only shifts slightly from 443 °C to 430 °C as catalyst is added at a CF ratio of 2. This difference in Tmax of 13 °C is significantly less than the Tmax difference of 173 °C that was observed for PP for this CF ratio. The catalytic degradation for PET is seen as a shoulder to the main degradation peak. As the CF ratio is increased, the size of the shoulder similarly increases, indicating that a higher percentage of PET is degrading via the catalyst. This higher percentage of catalytic degradation also corresponds with a higher percentage of solid residual left in the TGA crucible after the run. As the CF ratio increases from 0 to 0.5–1 to 2, the solid residual increases from 11.5 wt% to 14.0–20.9–24.2 wt% respectively. While PET forms solid residual in the absence of catalyst in the form of char, the increased CF ratio leads to an increase in solid residual which exists in the form of coke on the catalyst. For the co-pyrolysis of two polymers, an additive TGA curve can be calculated by referencing the TGA curves resulting from the pyrolysis of two polymers individually [12,29]. The additive curve is a prediction of the TGA curve that would result if no interactions between the polymers were to occur. The additive TGA curves for the co-pyrolysis of PP and PET at a 1:1 PP:PET ratio is plotted in Fig. 3, alongside the co-pyrolysis curves which were experimentally determined, for both non-catalytic pyrolysis and catalytic pyrolysis with a CF ratio of 1. The actual curve for the non-catalytic case closely mirrors the additive curve, indicating that for non-catalytic pyrolysis, there are not interactions between the two polymers affecting the degradation. For catalytic pyrolysis, some slight differences can be seen between the additive and actual TGA curves. For catalytic pyrolysis, two peaks appear which are indicative of PP degradation at lower temperatures, and PET degradation at higher temperatures. The maximum rate of degradation for PP is 15 % less than was expected from the additive curve, which could show that the presence of PET is slightly delaying the degradation of PP. Similar results were seen for the co-pyrolysis of LDPE and PET with HZSM-5, in that the maximum rate of LDPE degradation decreased 40 % from expected [12]. 3.2 Effect of catalyst deactivation on subsequent pyrolysis experiments The catalytic pyrolysis of PP with HZSM-5 at a CF ratio of 2 was conducted in order to obtain used catalyst, referred to as “Used Once” catalyst. The Used Once catalyst was then mixed with fresh PP powder again at a CF ratio of 2 and was subjected to the same pyrolysis experiment. The procedure was repeated once more with the Used Twice catalyst. The polymer weight percent curves and the derivative weight percent curves for these experiments, alongside the non-catalytic curves are plotted in Fig. 4. It can be seen that as the PP is used for consecutive runs with the same catalyst, that the catalyst begins to deactivate slightly, as the Tmax shifts from 280 °C, to 313 °C, and then to 340 °C. For all three uses of the catalyst, the degradation of PP is completed by 400 °C. Another interesting phenomenon that occurs is that as the catalyst is continually used, the solid residual begins to approach closer and closer to zero. Similar trends were also observed for the catalytic pyrolysis of LDPE with HZSM-5 [25]. In order to investigate the impact of PET on the catalyst deactivation, the co-pyrolysis of PP and PET was conducted with HZSM-5 at a CF ratio of 2, for various PP:PET ratios. In Fig. 5a, the resulting derivative weight percent curves for the catalytic co-pyrolysis of PP and PET at these various ratios is seen. It can be observed that regardless of the percentage of PET which is used, the Tmax value, indicative of PP degradation, is always centered at 282 °C. For higher ratios of PET, the secondary degradation peak centered at 420 °C begins to increase in intensity. For the various PP:PET ratios tested, the used catalyst was collected, and then used for catalytic pyrolysis at the same PP:PET ratio that was used for the fresh catalyst. The resulting derivative weight percent curves for the Used Once catalyst can be seen in Fig. 5b. It is seen that as higher percentages of PET are used in co-pyrolysis, the Tmax value for the used catalyst run shifts to higher temperatures. By adding 10 % PET, the Tmax value shifts from 313 °C to 345 °C. When 25 % PET is added, the Tmax shifts drastically to 463 °C, indicating that a high amount of PP is beginning to degrade non-catalytically, due to the deactivated catalyst. However, lower temperature degradation can also be observed in the range of 300 – 400 °C, indicating that some catalytic degradation of PP is still occurring. For the case of 50 % PET, no degradation is occurring below 400 °C, and the curve closely mirrors what is observed for the non-catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET at a 1:1 PP:PET ratio (Fig. S5). The shift back to the non-catalytic case indicates that at this level of PET, the catalyst is considered to be completely deactivated. 3.3 Characterization of fresh and used catalysts The total acidity and the external acidity of the fresh HZSM-5 catalyst, and the HZSM-5 coked by PP, and by PP and PET at a 1:1 PP:PET ratio, was determined via the temperature programmed desorption of pyridine and collidine. The resulting TPD curves for the three catalysts can be seen in Fig. 6, with the acidity results summarized in Table S2. The fresh HZSM-5 catalyst was observed to have 1.13 mmol of pyridine adsorbed per gram of catalyst. The external acidity of the fresh catalyst was shown to be 0.059 mmol of collidine per gram of catalyst. The three methyl groups on collidine cause it to be unable to adsorb to acid sites inside of the zeolite micropores, and only to acid sites on the external surface of the zeolite. The collidine accessibility factor can be determined by dividing the external acidity by the total acidity, and for the fresh catalyst this was determined to be 5.2 %. Untreated zeolites are known to have low collidine accessibility factors in the range of 4–9 %, as most of the acid sites are found within the pores [30]. For the catalyst coked by PP, the total acidity of the catalyst decreased by 18 % to a level of 0.94 mmol pyridine per gram of catalyst. When the catalyst was coked by a 1:1 mixture of PP and PET, the acidity decreased further by 35 % to a level of 0.70 mmol pyridine per gram of catalyst. The external acidity decreased by 61 % to 0.023 mmol Coll/gcat for the catalyst coked by PP and decreased by 92 % for the catalyst coked by a 1:1 mixture of PP and PET. The collidine accessibility factor, which is defined as the external acidity divided by the total acidity, dropped to 2.5 % for catalyst coked by PP, and dropped further to 0.7 % for the catalyst coked by PP and PET. This low collidine accessibility factor observed for the catalyst coked by PP and PET, indicates that coke from PET is preferentially forming on the external acid sites of the catalyst. Surface analysis results from nitrogen physisorption experiments also show the preferential formation of coke from PET on external acid sites. Surface analysis plots for the same fresh and used catalysts studied with pyridine and collidine TPD are shown in Fig. 7. The reported surface areas and pore volumes calculated from the experiments are listed in Table S2. For catalyst that is coked by PP, the micropore area was observed to drop from 310 m2/g to 288 m2/g (-22 m2/g) and the external surface area was observed to drop from 105 m2/g to 86 m2/g (-19 m2/g), indicating a more substantial drop in micropore area. For the catalyst coked by PP and PET, the micropore area dropped to 260 m2/g (-50 m2/g) and the external surface area dropped to 45 m2/g (-60 m2/g), indicating a more substantial drop in the external surface area. This result is mirrored for the change in micropore and mesopore volume. Micropore volume decreases by 0.014 m3/g and mesopore volume decreased by 0.002 m3/g for PP/cbv2314, where for PP+PET/cbv2314, micropore volume decreases by 0.026 m3/g and mesopore volume decreases by 0.030 m3/g. The surface analysis results indicate that for both PP and PET coke is forming on both internal acid sites inside micropore and on external acid sites on the surface and in mesopores, but there is a preference for coke for PP to form more internally, and for coke from PET to form more externally. The limited amount of external acid sites on the catalyst coked by PP and PET can help to explain the severe deactivation which was observed for this catalyst in Fig. 5b. External acid sites have been shown to be necessary for the low temperature degradation of branched polymers such as LLDPE [31]. By poisoning the external acid sites of HZSM-5 with collidine, it was shown that the catalytic degradation of polyethylene does not occur at low temperatures in which degradation does occur for the non-poisoned catalyst [32]. Our results further confirm the necessity for external acid sites to facilitate the low temperature degradation of PP and show that PET can lead to coking which prevents access to these important catalytic sites. 3.4 Isoconversional approach for activation energy determination The non-catalytic pyrolysis and the catalytic pyrolysis (CF = 1) of PP and PET were conducted at heating rates of 5, 10, and 20 °C min−1. The resulting polymer weight percent curves, as well as the associated conversion curves are displayed in Fig. S6. The FWO method was used to determine the apparent activation energy for each of the pyrolysis experiments. In the FWO approach, the apparent activation energy is determined for each conversion level. The associated plots for whose slope are used for calculation of the activation energies are displayed in Fig. S7. The resulting activation energies, pre-exponential factors, and r-squared values for these plots are listed in Table S3 and Table S4. The activation energy determined for conversion values between 0.1 and 0.9 are plotted in Fig. 8. It can be seen that for the non-catalytic pyrolysis of PP, activation energies lie in the range of 190 kJ mol−1 to 216 kJ mol−1, leading to an average activation energy of 209 kJ mol−1. This activation energy falls well within the range of activation energies reported for the non-catalytic pyrolysis of PP [33]. For the catalytic pyrolysis of PP, the apparent activation energy starts at 102 kJ mol−1 for a conversion of 0.1 and decreases to 72 kJ mol−1 as the conversion increases to 0.9. This downward trend of activation energies in a similar range was also observed for the catalytic pyrolysis of PP with nanocrystalline HZSM-5 (CF =1), as the activation energy decreased from 97 kJ mol−1 to 75 kJ mol−1 as the conversion increased from 0.1 to 0.9 [34]. For the non-catalytic pyrolysis of PET, activation energies lie between 178 mol−1 and 197 kJ mol- 1. Similar results were observed by Perez et al. for the non-catalytic pyrolysis of PET, with activation energies between 186 and 199 kJ mol−1 observed [29]. For the catalytic pyrolysis of PET, the activation energy started at 173 kJ mol−1 but then increases to 209 kJ mol-1 as the conversion was increased from 0.1 to 0.9. It was observed in Fig. 2 the inability of HZSM-5 to decrease the Tmax for PET pyrolysis regardless of the CF ratio used, which leads to similar activation energies whether with or without catalyst. For low conversion values < 0.4, the activation energy is slightly decreased with the catalyst, but as the conversion increases, the activation energy becomes larger for the catalytic pyrolysis. This can be due to the formation of coke on the catalyst, which hinders the reaction. Dubdub et al. reported a lower activation energy of 143 kJ mol−1 for the catalytic pyrolysis of PET with H-Beta (CF = 0.25), however a similar Tmax (437 °C) was observed to the Tmax observed in our study (434 °C) for a 10 °C min−1 heating rate [35]. 3.5 Nth-order kinetic modelling results The resulting kinetic parameters which were found to optimize the fit for the 28 experimental conditions are shown in Table 1. The average fit% for the weight% curves was 97.7 % with a minimum fit% of 94.9 %. The fit% for the derivative weight% curves were found to be lower, with an average fit% of 94.5 % and a minimum value of 87.7 %. Fig. 9 shows selected experimental curves plotted with their modelling counterpart. Fig. 9a and b show the experimental and model curves for the catalytic pyrolysis of PET at various CF ratios. As was discussed in Section 3.1, as the CF ratio is increased, the amount of solid residual left from the pyrolysis experiment also increases. This same trend of larger solid residual for larger CF ratios was able to be observed in the model curves. This is due to larger CF ratios leading to a higher percentage of PET degrading via the catalytic pathway, compared to degrading via the non-catalytic pathway. Due to a higher value of δ (0.874) obtained from the optimization, in comparison with the value for ε obtained for PET catalytic pyrolysis (0.669), the non-catalytic pathway (R3) leads to a lower solid residual. Fig. S8 shows the temperature dependent species balance for PET catalytic pyrolysis which results from the model. As the CF ratio is increased, the ratio of volatiles formed from the catalytic pathway (G4) to volatiles formed from the non-catalytic pathway (G3), as well as the ratio of CokeT to Char, are increased, indicating a higher extent of catalytic degradation. Fig. 9c and d show the experimental and model curves for the catalytic pyrolysis of PP with a CF ratio of 2 for multiple catalytic runs. The model is able to accurately capture the upward shift in degradation temperature as the catalyst is used in its successive runs. This is due to the incorporation of the catalyst activity terms ( ϕ pol , # ) which were introduced in Eq. (5). For the fresh catalyst ϕP,1 and ϕP,2 are both equal to 1. For the used once catalyst, the values of ϕP,1 and ϕP,2 decreased to values of 0.214 and 0.493 respectively. For the used twice catalyst, the values of ϕP,1 and ϕP,2 decreased further to values of 0.118 and 0.375. The constants of dP1,P and dP2,P which give rise to the decreased catalyst activity were optimized to be 0.498 and 0.229 respectively, which were close in magnitude to the deactivation constant of 0.543 which was obtained by Marcilla et al. for the catalytic pyrolysis of LDPE with HZSM-5, while utilizing a single step kinetic modelling pathway [25]. In addition to predicting higher degradation temperatures as the catalyst is further used, the model is also able to predict a decrease in the formed solid residual. The solid residual was predicted to decrease from 6.11 wt% to 2.32 wt% and then to 1.95 wt% for the second and third runs, closely matching the experimental results. Fig. 9e and f show the experimental and model curves for the used once catalyst runs for the co-pyrolysis of PP and PET at various PP:PET ratios containing 10 %, 25 %, and 50 % PET. As higher percentages of PET are included, the deactivation becomes more severe, leading to polymer degradation at higher temperatures. The catalyst activity for the first step of PP catalytic degradation, denoted as ϕP,1, decrease from a value of 0.0908 to 0.0086 as the percentage of PET increases from 10 % to 25 %. Further increasing the PET percentage to 50 % further decreases ϕP,1 to a value of 0.00004. The decrease in catalyst activity for PP leads to an increase in the percent of non-catalytic degradation of PP which occurs for the used catalyst runs. For the case of 10 % PET, all the PP degrades catalytically, for 25 % PET there is a combination of catalytic and non-catalytic degradation of PP, and for the case of 50 % PET there is only non-catalytic degradation of PP, as shown in Fig. S9. In addition to the decrease in catalyst activity for PP via the deactivation constants, a larger reaction order of 2.337 for nC,P1_C helps for the modelling of used catalysts with higher percentages of PET. Since the reaction kinetics are dependent on mass fraction, which can never exceed a value of 1, a higher reaction order is reasonable. Due to the high value of b (5.045) obtained for the PET catalytic pathway (R4), PET is able to easily saturate the catalytic sites, bringing the mass fraction of [C] to low values. The high reaction order for nC,P1_C then makes the catalytic pathway for PP less favorable, leading to a higher extent of non-catalytic degradation for PP. The corresponding experimental and model profiles for the fresh catalyst runs with varying PP:PET ratios are shown in Fig. S10. It is observed that the model is able to fit well the degradation which occurs at lower temperatures for the catalytic co-pyrolysis of PP and PET with the fresh HZSM-5 catalyst. In addition to predicting polymer degradation for the CF ratio, catalyst use state, and PP:PET ratio used, the kinetic modelling was also able to predict degradation behavior for various heating rates which were used. Fig. S11 shows the experimental and modelling results for both the non-catalytic and the catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET at various heating rates. The model is able to predict well the increase in degradation temperature that occurs as the heating rate is increased. The ability of the nth order kinetic modelling approach to predict degradation profiles for various heating rates is one advantage of the technique, which has also been observed by others [18]. To further validate the robustness of our kinetic model, we conducted two additional experiments under new operating conditions involving different PP:PET ratios (1:1 and 1:3), CF ratios (1:1 and 1.5:1), and heating rates (10 and 40 °C min−1) that were not included in the model optimization process. We then applied the optimized parameters obtained for the nth-order model to test these new cases without modifying any parameter values. The resulting fits are presented in Table S5 while Fig. S12 shows the experimental and modelling results obtained under these conditions. Fig. S12 shows excellent agreement between the experimental and model-predicted DTG and weight loss profiles. These results confirm that the nth-order model generalizes well across different experimental conditions and validates the model accuracy of the fitted parameters beyond the training dataset. 4 Conclusion In this study, the catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET was conducted with HZSM-5 catalyst in a thermogravimetric analyzer at various CF ratios, PP:PET ratios, and heating rates. It was observed that as the CF ratio was increased, the total solid residual left at the end of pyrolysis also increased, for both PP and for PET. The addition of HZSM-5 drastically decreased the maximum degradation temperature for PP (110–181 °C difference), while only decreasing the degradation temperature slightly for PET (10–13 °C difference). The average apparent activation energy for PP pyrolysis, determined via FWO approach, decreased from 209 mol−1 to 87 mol−1 when HZSM-5 catalyst was added at CF ratio of 1. The activation energy for PET only decreased in the conversion range of 0.1 – 0.4 when HZSM-5 catalyst was added. Catalyst deactivation phenomena was investigated by running subsequent pyrolysis experiments with used catalysts for the pyrolysis experiments. A shift to higher degradation temperatures was observed for the used catalysts. When higher percentages of PET were included in the pyrolysis, a larger shift to higher temperatures was observed for the used catalysts, indicating that PET was deactivating the catalyst to a higher extent. Pyridine and collidine TPD revealed that catalyst coked by both PP and PET resulted in the lowest collidine accessibility factor (0.7 %) when compared to catalyst coked only by PP (2.5 %) and fresh catalyst (5.2 %). This indicates that coke from PET was preferentially forming on external acid sites. This finding was supported by nitrogen physisorption, which revealed that catalyst coked by PP and PET resulted in a larger decrease in its external surface area (-60 m2/g) than its micropore area (-50 m2/g), where catalyst coked by PP resulted in smaller decrease in its external surface area (-19 m2/g) than its micropore area (-22 m2/g). Coke from PET forming on, and thus deactivating, external acid sites, can explain the deactivation phenomenon observed in our catalytic co-pyrolysis experiments with PP and PET in the TGA, as it is well documented that external acid sites are necessary for the catalytic degradation of PP and other polyolefins [31,32,36]. Future works targeting catalyst design for the catalytic pyrolysis of mixed plastic waste should investigate whether coke from PET can be directed towards acid sites on the catalyst, which are different than the acid sites necessary for the catalytic degradation of PP and other polyolefins. An nth order reaction scheme was used to model the catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET with both the fresh and used catalysts. A good fit of the model to the experimental results were observed for 30 different experimental conditions of various CF ratios, PP:PET ratios, heating rates, and catalyst use states, through the optimization of 37 kinetic parameters. The kinetic modelling was able to predict the extent of polymer degradation which occurs catalytically and non-catalytically, for experiments with high percentages of PET, and with used catalysts, in which a mix of catalytic and non-catalytic degradation is thought to occur. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic pyrolysis and co-pyrolysis of PP and PET with HZSM-5 zeolite catalyst was conducted for various catalyst to feedstock (CF) ratios, PP to PET ratios, and heating rates using a thermogravimetric analyzer (TGA). The Flynn-Wall-Ozawa (FWO) isoconversional approach was used to determine apparent activation energies for the non-catalytic and catalytic pyrolysis of PP and PET. An nth-order reaction scheme was used to model the pyrolysis at various operating conditions through the optimization of the associated kinetic parameters. Additional TGA experiments were conducted with used catalysts to gain insight into catalyst deactivation, and it was found that the inclusion of PET led to more severe deactivation. Collidine temperature programmed desorption (TPD) indicated the loss of external acid sites for catalysts coked by PET pyrolysis, explaining the severe deactivation. Catalyst deactivation was incorporated into the kinetic modelling approach, so that degradation profiles could be predicted for experiments with the used catalysts.
